abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Emergency Assistance Project (EAP) in
            Burundi. While the overall Emergency Recovery Program (ERP)
            proved to be too optimistic, the general objectives of the
            more modest EAP were achieved, despite the unstable
            environment during its implementation. The EAP succeeded in
            its primary objective to direct emergency resources to the
            sectors most in need, and it is likely that without the EAP,
            it would have been very difficult to prevent further
            deterioration in the economic and social conditions.
            However, the EAP was not very successful in its secondary
            objective to act as a catalyst for mobilizing donor support
            for the broader ERP. The ERP's failure can be
            attributed to: (i) its design, specifically to the fact that
            donor technical work and participation in preparing the ERP
            were very limited, and more extensive consultations were
            needed to identify the priority activities for the targeted
            sectors prior to the Paris meeting; and (ii) to the
            deterioration of the political situation which discouraged
            donors from carrying out their pledges in the context of the
            ERP. Overall, any operation --development or otherwise--
            implemented in an environment where a stable socio-political
            setting is lacking, has limited chances of achieving
            sustainable results. Close evaluation of the situation,
            careful program design, and the need of realism are
            necessary before committing to such broad recovery programs.
